head.supplied: Dear Sir, ¶ ¶ I hasten to give you a short reply to your two last letters ¶ and to inform you that I am just about two hours since arrived in Melbourne and as there is a vessell just sailing for Ade...

div.p: RB MSS M36, Library, Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne.

MS envelope front: 'Dr F Müller | care of | Messrs Büttner & Heuzenroeder | Chemists & Druggists | Rundle Street | Adelaide'. Front post-marked GPO, South Australia, 16 April 1852. The letter is dated to April on this evidence of receipt in Adelaide.
For a summary of this letter see Daley (1935), p. 156. Dear Sir,

I hasten to give you a short reply to your two last letters
Letters not found. and to inform you that I am just about two hours since arrived in Melbourne and as there is a vessell just sailing for Adelaide I thought I would take the opportunity of letting you know where I am, you have no doubt been anxiously expecting to hear from me & I had written part of a letter before leaving Hobarton, but being uncertain where I should be I had not put in the post, in fact I have been so unsettled lately that I could give you no account of my address — this place seems very flourishing from what I see in the few hours I have been here, but nothing I think in my line, I am not able to go to the diggings for want of means & shall therefore endeavour to obtain some employment here for a time — in fact untill I see you, which meeting I anticipate with much pleasure so do please write to me as soon as you receive this, I have a box of specimens for you but unfortunately I cannot get them from the hold of the vessel in time to send by this conveyance

I just write this in much haste being determined to put you out of suspense respecting me so you will excuse my speaking on botanical matters but long to see you when I anticipate much pleasure & think that I have many specimens that will please you, the result of my late imperfect researches, some I believe new, others rare from South Port, Recherche Bay
Tas. &c — I have just now about 5/. in my pocket so must look out for something to recruit my finances being a stranger here — I feel highly flattered and honoured by the eminent distinction you have procured me
Sonder and M named two plants for Stuart in Sonder (1852a): Helipterum stuartianum (p. 518) and Polycalymma stuartii (p. 494), both collected by the Murray River. Stuart may have been referring to one or both of them in this letter. The specimen of H. stuartianum from Sonder's herbarium, MEL 604830, carries M's label giving this name on his own authority. The undated specimen of P. stuartii, MEL 542214 that has been designated a syntype is not from Sonder's herbarium and is not collected from the locality given in the protologue. & believe me that I shall when circumstances permit resume our favorite pursuit with fresh ardour

In the meantime I beg you to write to me to say when I may expect you here & I will not leave, you will perceive by this that I am very unsettled — I must close this short letter as the mail is just closing I must run to the Post office
